resources.string: Ad hominem is an insult used as if it were an argument or evidence in support of a conclusion.
With the strawman argument, someone attacks a position the opponent doesn’t really hold.
An appeal to ignorance isn’t proof of anything except that you don’t know something.
Dilemma-based arguments are only fallacious when, in fact, there are more than the stated options.
The slippery slope fallacy suggests that unlikely or ridiculous outcomes are likely when there’s just not enough evidence to think so.

Circular arguments are also called Petitio principii, meaning “Assuming the initial [thing]” (commonly mistranslated as “begging the question”). This fallacy is a kind of presumptuous argument where it only appears to be an argument.
Hasty generalization may be the most common logical fallacy because there’s no single agreed-upon measure for “sufficient” evidence.
A “red herring fallacy” is a distraction from the argument typically with some sentiment that seems to be relevant but isn’t really on-topic.
The “tu quoque,” Latin for “you too,” is also called the “appeal to hypocrisy” because it distracts from the argument by pointing out hypocrisy in the opponent.
The causal fallacy is any logical breakdown when identifying a cause.
Fallacy of Sunk Costs. Fo example, when we invest ourselves so thoroughly in a project that we’re reluctant to ever abandon it, even when it turns out to be fruitless and futile
Appeal to Authority (argumentum ad verecundiam)This fallacy happens when we misuse an authority.
Equivocation happens when a word, phrase, or sentence is used deliberately to confuse, deceive, or mislead by sounding like it’s saying one thing but actually saying something else.

Argumentum ad misericordiam is Latin for “argument to compassion.” Like the ad hominem fallacy above, it is a fallacy of relevance. Personal attacks, and emotional appeals, aren’t strictly relevant to whether something is true or false
The bandwagon fallacy assumes something is true (or right, or good) because other people agree with it.
